reviews.text: There’s not only pain and heartache in that reflection by the fire, but also a tinge of hope and relief. It’s astounding in how powerful it is.
reviews.author: JD Duran

reviews.text: It would be easy, but superficial, to lump Call Me by Your Name as just a romance film between two young men, but director Luca Guadagnino thankfully has a lot more on his mind.
reviews.author: Brendan Cassidy

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name skips through time like a dream, or a calcified, powerful memory. Guadagnino succeeds remarkably in working the themes into the craft and, like love that ends too soon, so does the film.
reviews.author: Benedict Seal

reviews.text: Luca Guadagnino’s lush Italian masterpiece, “Call Me by Your Name,” is full of romantic subtleties: long lingering looks, brief touches, meaning-laden passages read aloud. But nothing is ever fully overt...
reviews.author: Mira Fox

reviews.text: From the 1980s idyllic Italian countryside to the slow-burn romance, Luca Guadagnino directs a mesmerizingly dreamy summer experience.
reviews.author: Jennifer Bisset

reviews.text: The film is romantic in a very classical sense, and the spell works.
reviews.author: Vadim Rizov

reviews.text: 17-year-old Elio (Timothée Chalamet, in his best performance to date) lives with his parents in suburban Northern Italy. Elio's archaeologist papa (Michael Stuhlbarg) invites an American grad student (the always-wooden Armie Hammer), to spend the summer..
reviews.author: Frank J. Avella

reviews.text: Chalamet rocketed from obscurity onto the Hollywood A-List thanks to Call Me By Your Name, and with good reason: he didnt just give a great performance in the film, he gave the best performance of 2017.
reviews.author: David Reddish

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name taps into universal emotions that belong to everyone who has loved, and rewards our experience through luscious filmmaking.
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name is a film that captures a human truth in a way like no others.
reviews.author: Carson Timar

reviews.text: While it's the simmering sexual tension that keeps you watching for most of the film, it's only later that you realise this is a character piece about a man's bluster and how his confidence does not make him strong.
reviews.author: Ben Turner

reviews.text: The most humane and kind movie in a year that featured so many others filled with anxiety and darkness.
reviews.author: Fletcher Powell

reviews.text: Chalamet's performance is magnificent - this is the sort of performance that stretches across a lifetime. This is "Hey look we have our own James Dean now" level good stuff here
reviews.author: Jason Adams

reviews.text: The blossoming romance between these two men, that unfurls over six sun-dappled weeks in northern Italy, is utterly ravishing.
reviews.author: Yasmin Omar

reviews.text: What the film does with that, thanks to the performance by 2017 all-star Michael Stuhlbarg, is surprising and life-affirming.
reviews.author: Ian Brill

reviews.text: Chalamet is quickly becoming one of the most reliable young actors around...
reviews.author: David Bax

reviews.text: The actors are superbly convincing.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: It's certainly a handsome piece of escapist-touristic fantasy, though I remain skeptical of Guadagnino, who often seems truer to his sideline as a luxury-product advertiser than he does to the narrative and psychological depth...
reviews.author: Dennis Harvey

reviews.text: One of 2017's most engaging and loving films.
reviews.author: Richard Propes

reviews.text: [I]ncredibly seedy and oft-fetishized . . . In the world of Call Me by Your Name, this sort of behavior is literal, and it's abusive.
reviews.author: Matt Cipolla

reviews.text: Chalamet's performance is subtle but thorough, his body language conveys so many feelings... his stare is the reflection of the love he desires. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ricardo Gallegos

reviews.text: [T]here is nothing else in their world of two, no other possible reference ... The film is powerful not in spite of the fact that it's a summer fling, but because of it.
reviews.author: CJ Sheu

reviews.text: It frames the honesty of human feelings with a lucidity that transcends any sexual sphere. It is a good movie. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Yasser Medina

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name transcends because it dares to not only ask, but also answer the question posed by so many love stories throughout history: was the love worth the pain? Yes. Without a doubt, it was.
reviews.author: Alton Williams

reviews.text: A delicious boy-meets-boy romance.
reviews.author: David Lamble

reviews.text: The director's use of location is almost too good to be true, and will likely make you want to book at trip to Italy immediately.
reviews.author: Steven Prokopy

reviews.text: I still enjoyed a lot of this movie.
reviews.author: Avaryl Halley

reviews.text: There wasn't nearly enough Italy porn or gay porn.
reviews.author: Andrew Galdi

reviews.text: A modern-day Visconti, Italian director Luca Guadagnino (I Am Love) grants us entry into a world not only of wealth but of culture, which can be just as liberating.
reviews.author: J. R. Jones

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name is one of the most beautiful films I saw in 2017, but ultimately it left me unsettled.
reviews.author: Megan Purdy

reviews.text: The movie contributes little to the urgent contemporary project of diversifying representation... Yet, for two hours and change, Call Me By Your Name is an overwhelmingly pleasant and seductive place to live.
reviews.author: James Loop

reviews.text: The film (adapted by James Ivory) is beyond lovely and methodical, covering every aspect of the life of an adolescent at a critical moment of his growth.
reviews.author: Jorge Ignacio Castillo

reviews.text: Guadagnino has absorbed some of that Merchant Ivory mojo, with its sotto vocce emotions and divine European languor. But he's also fallen victim to his inspiration's vices as well.
reviews.author: Chris McCoy

reviews.text: A timeless and sumptuous tale of the rarity and fullness of love.
reviews.author: Aly Caviness

reviews.text: At its heart, Call Me By Your Name is bittersweet, melancholic yet ultimately uplifting - just like first love.
reviews.author: Katie Smith-Wong

reviews.text: It is a lyrical, mesmerizing, experience at the cinema that numbers among the best movies of the year.
reviews.author: Leslie Combemale

reviews.text: This film is a beautifully shot lavish love letter to Italy, but even more, the slow unfolding of a love affair that meant something to two men who knew it would not continue.
reviews.author: Linda and Al Lerner

reviews.text: This gently provocative new film is an insightful portrait of not just the awkward ungainliness of first love, but the intensely defining nature of how its effects define identities and trajectories.
reviews.author: Nicholas Bell

reviews.text: Their love story is one for the cinematic ages.
reviews.author: Kate Rodger

reviews.text: For such a simple story, the thematic depths that Call Me By Your Name covers is incredibly impressive.
reviews.author: Karl Delossantos

reviews.text: 'Call Me By Your Name' is a wonder, a film that leaves you with a smile on your face and with a good feeling similar to that unexpected breeze on a hot summer afternoon. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Mikel Zorrilla

reviews.text: It is precisely its honesty that makes it an indelible, charmingly melancholic journey. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jorge Loser

reviews.text: A lovely film that works on various levels, not least being its insistence on lush visual cues.
reviews.author: Matt Brunson

reviews.text: Love my way.
reviews.author: Michael J. Casey

reviews.text: A masterpiece; a wise, wonderful, and perfectly crafted romance that lingers and enchants, standing tall as one of the finest cinematic achievements in recent memory.
reviews.author: Mattie Lucas

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name is an exquisite queer love story that might be through the lens of two gay men, but it speaks to the hearts of everyone, everywhere.
reviews.author: Beth McDonough

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name is a visually stunning film and a romantic tale of forbidden love.
reviews.author: Cate Marquis

reviews.text: A beautiful film.
reviews.author: Dan Murrell

reviews.text: Luca Guadagnino's film is sumptuous, sultry, and sincere. It's soaked with sensuality but defined by restrained tension and yearning expectation.
reviews.author: Marshall Shaffer

reviews.text: Its refreshing to watch a movie which embraces the past without sacrificing the present.
reviews.author: Wendy Shreve

reviews.text: While making comparisons is nearly always reductive, Call Me By Your Name feels like Brokeback Mountain via Richard Linklater - which hopefully sounds like a compliment because it is meant as a huge one.
reviews.author: Christopher Preston

reviews.text: I enjoyed the leisurely pace and the great writing by James Ivory.
reviews.author: Rachel Wagner

reviews.text: An utterly triumphant work of art.
reviews.author: Doug Jamieson

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name resembles the passionate love story it depicts in many ways. It's one of those breathtaking cinematic experiences which demands to be called a "film" rather than a "movie."
reviews.author: Andrea Thompson

reviews.text: A stunning film - a sensual feast filled with desire.
reviews.author: Fiona Underhill

reviews.text: Guadagnino's film looks like idealized young love feels. It's as warm, lush, and timeless as a sacred Apollonian grove.
reviews.author: Andrew Wyatt

reviews.text: Guadanigno is not interested in creating a story about sin, but rather one about joy, goodbyes and the loss that involves love. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Luis Fernando Galván

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name is a masterfully told story about first love, hidden sexual desire and coming-of-age experiences capped with great performances, immersive production values and nuanced direction that will surely dazzle the eyes and warm your heart.
reviews.author: Harris Dang

reviews.text: Guadagnino creates a perfectly judged atmosphere of melancholy, longing, tranquillity and inner turmoil as the heat of the summer engulfs Elio with a rising attraction to Oliver.
reviews.author: Lewis Knight

reviews.text: It's charming, it's pleasing, it's a bit sexy, it takes apricots to places they've never been before - but it's a strong movie with wonderful messages, subtexts and delivery.
reviews.author: Matt Hudson

reviews.text: A stunning coming-of-age tale that will go down in gay cinema history.
reviews.author: Joe Passmore

reviews.text: By the end of the film, when Michael Stuhlbarg delivers what is surely one of modern cinema's most achingly beautiful monologues, I was a puddle.
reviews.author: Di Golding

reviews.text: Guadagnino delivers one of the year's most striking, eloquent films... Each moment feels pulled out of a different era, transporting viewers in a way only cinema masters can.
reviews.author: Matt Ward

reviews.text: Gorgeous to look at but with a barebones plot that struggles to keep things chipping along and some questionable statutory dilemmas, I found myself hovering on the edge of attention when I should have been diving in head first.
reviews.author: Matt Oakes

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name has been marketed as a gay romance, yet less overt is its inclusion of Jewish culture.
reviews.author: Li Lai

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name is an unapologetic celebration of emotion.
reviews.author: Ian Thomas Malone

reviews.text: An observational character piece that's meant to be experienced in terms of visual beauty, erotic charge and thoughtful contemplation on the intensity and brevity of youth and love.
reviews.author: Bob Chipman

reviews.text: It's a very astute study of the struggles of a young man trying to find out who he is and struggling between relationships -- both conventional and forbidden by society.
reviews.author: Micheal Compton

reviews.text: Here is a film that shuns conventions expected in coming-of-age stories and romances but never at the expense of universal emotions felt by anyone who has ever been in love.
reviews.author: Sean Mulvihill

reviews.text: Guadagnino's adaptation of André Aciman's novel is a wonderfully sensitive and evocative portrait of young love, but lost in time somewhere in Northern Italy, Call Me By Your Name gets caught up in the outdated politics of its day.
reviews.author: Alexa Dalby

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name is a staggeringly beautiful film that brings together a fully fleshed out artistic vision ... as well as a host of brilliant performances from its cast.
reviews.author: Kimberly Pierce

reviews.text: Where so many Hollywood "gay" stories end on positive notes of rebirth and optimism, Guadagnino helms a love story unafraid to highlight the suffering one always contains.
reviews.author: Jared Mobarak

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name survives because of poignant screenwriting, keen directing, and tender acting.
reviews.author: Robert Daniels

reviews.text: Right when I begin to feel fatigued by "coming of age" movies, this comes out and blows me away.
reviews.author: Rendy Jones

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name doesn't insist on your attention for much of its two-hour running length; it lets you fall in and out, its scenes glazed with a nostalgia that almost encourages personal reminisces.
reviews.author: Molly Templeton

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name is a romantic masterpiece and, quite possibly, my favourite film of the year.
reviews.author: Hannah Ryan

reviews.text: In one singular space, you feel insecure, confident, charismatic, inferior and completely clueless, as if it were a revolving door never allowing you to stop and walk through, towards something bigger, maybe even something grown up.
reviews.author: Ella Kemp

reviews.text: A compelling, confusing, beautiful film peopled with unforgettable, believable characters, not necessarily a crowd pleaser, but an intense, highly individual vision that might open your eyes to what the definition of "summer romance" can mean.
reviews.author: Asia Frey

reviews.text: By opting against a graphic depiction of the characters' carnal consummation, it causes that spark of first love Elio is coming to terms with to linger more pervasively. That warmth exuding from the screen is "Call Me by Your Name's" gift to you.
reviews.author: Rubén Rosario

reviews.text: I find it strangely hypocritical that Hollywood is so willing to celebrate the behavior on film that it so vehemently condemns in real life... Call Me By Your Name is creepy, not cool.
reviews.author: Lisa Johnson Mandell

reviews.text: It works well as a coming of age story and examination of how people communicate when they are unsure of the other's feelings.
reviews.author: Rosalynn Try-Hane

reviews.text: Chalamet's performance ascends into the pantheon of greats, a mixture of Marlon Brando's brimming panic and Heath Ledger's simmering vulnerability.
reviews.author: Glenn Heath Jr.

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name is a stronger film than the director's last film, A Bigger Splash, and employs touches of pure emotion that will tug at your heart.
reviews.author: Mae Abdulbaki

reviews.text: Oliver being a whole person instead of a dreamboat would have elevated this movie to the first rank. But go see this movie, bask in the sunshine and feel your heart growing three sizes larger.
reviews.author: Sarah Manvel

reviews.text: There is much to relish in this passionate, visually rich romance...that particularly excels in its refreshing take on the permissiveness that's possible through liberalism guided by knowledge and experience.
reviews.author: Craig Takeuchi

reviews.text: The era of LGBT cinema has reached a zenith with this film.
reviews.author: Wesley Lovell

reviews.text: Surprisingly, given how hyper-articulate everyone is, the duo's most potent scenes are wordless, conveying a wealth of emotion in glances and gestures.
reviews.author: Jason Best

reviews.text: In a technical sense, Guadagnino understands how to transition between these moments, allowing the film to breathe effortlessly into the next as scenes are woven together with cross dissolves and fades rather than harsh cuts.
reviews.author: Morgan Rojas

reviews.text: It is the transmission of halcyon and the ensuing tragedy of its evaporation that Guadagnino nails in his adaptation.
reviews.author: Rich Juzwiak

reviews.text: There is a preciseness in the performances in Luca Guadagnino's Call Me By Your Name that is not just enchanting but also essential in turning the gentle romance into something substantial and profound.
reviews.author: Oggs Cruz

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name's strength is that it really does seem like the character played by Timothée Chalamet made the film himself.
reviews.author: A.S. Hamrah

reviews.text: The chemistry between the leading men grows organically and it chronologically makes sense for the viewer. These characters take time to feel comfortable with each other and the film takes its time documenting it.
reviews.author: Stephan Boissonneault

reviews.text: The characters' beauty and intellectual perfection is so consummate that I couldn't entirely believe that these people actually had genitals-that they could ever sweat or incur sunburn.
reviews.author: Jonathan Romney

reviews.text: ...a fascinating study of fleeting love, proving that a lot can be done when you favor characterisation and atmosphere over traditional narrative. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Sebastian Zavala Kahn

reviews.text: Director Luca Guadagnino has infused Call Me by Your Name with an unhurried and excessively languid sensibility that becomes more and more problematic as time progresses...
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: A universal story that conquers with empathy and delicacy as very few love stories have in the history of cinema. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Emmanuel Báez

reviews.text: A fine coming-of-age ode to first love.
reviews.author: Dennis Schwartz

reviews.text: It ends up being quite moving, supported by excellent performances to create an effective drama. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Carlos Díaz Reyes

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name is a film made with great care. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: William Venegas

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name sees Italian filmmaker Luca Guadagnino do his home country proud with an absolutely gorgeous depiction of the northern Italian countryside.
reviews.author: Ben Sin

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name does more harm than good, and needed to be and do more. Especially as yet another queer white cisgender-centric film, it should have aimed for the stars instead of aiming to make people feel comfortable.
reviews.author: Jamal Grootboom

reviews.text: [Director Luca Guadagnino] seems to give body and soul to Call Me by Your Name. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Nazareno Brega

reviews.text: The layered, lovely script is rich with an understanding of life and loss that comes only with age.
reviews.author: Loren King

reviews.text: I appreciated the film quality and the acting but the story meandered in superficial courtship for too long without delivering actual connection. It was all foreplay and no action. Perhaps the sequel will make this film more appealing to me in the future.
reviews.author: Alachia Queen

reviews.text: Destined, almost certainly, to become a queer film classic. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Diego Lerer

reviews.text: ... Many of the best moments illustrate the experiences of [Timothy Chlamaet] in the solitary privacy of his room. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Felipe Vicente

reviews.text: A sweet and loving film where the characters are less mindful of an outside response and more consumed by the amorous temptations they possess.
reviews.author: David Keyes

reviews.text: Anyone who has experienced the flush of first love will relate, but the fact that the film is specific and detailed both emotionally and physically in its portrayal of a gay relationship makes it a standout.
reviews.author: Eric Melin

reviews.text: A song to life. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Roger Salvans

reviews.text: It is not only lovely to look at (the exquisite northern Italian countryside made me want to hop on a plane that moment), but is made even better by the subtle performance of Timothée Chalamet.
reviews.author: Diane Pershing

reviews.text: It is a brilliant, moving and charming film that delves into self-discovery and is perfect for this century. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Marco Cubillo

reviews.text: This is a beautiful film -- one that is startlingly real. It feels so blisteringly sensual and in the moment, that it's almost impossible to ignore.
reviews.author: Chris Stuckmann

reviews.text: The drama is filled with raw emotions and evinces an incredible honesty in terms of storytelling. The filmmaking style reflects, even more, the vivid three-dimensionality of the characters.
reviews.author: Filipe Freitas

reviews.text: There's no way to convey why I dislike the film so much without giving out major spoilers later in this review, so be warned if you're really dying to see this 132-minute, morally bankrupt snoozefest.
reviews.author: Carl Kozlowski

reviews.text: This Best Picture nominee is a beautifully filmed coming-of-age and coming-out story.
reviews.author: tt stern-enzi

reviews.text: The result is enveloping and moving. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Daniel Krauze

reviews.text: It breathes and evokes the essence of a landscape that throughout the centuries has been sometimes Italian and sometimes Gallic, but always Mediterranean to the marrow: a fertile ground for love or desire. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Sergio Huidobro

reviews.text: "Call Me By Your Name" can be considered an idealistic film, but that's only natural for something about young people experiencing something wonderful for the first time.
reviews.author: Jordan Hoffman

reviews.text: Some of the scenery in the film, including a waterfall, is spectacular. The location shots are sumptuous. The acting is subtle and moving. This film has a lot going for it, but it is also very low-key, relatively non-dramatic and slow-moving.
reviews.author: Robert Roten

reviews.text: It's an extraordinary thing for a narrative film to successfully observe its characters like they aren't of its own creation - to make them utterly alive in front of us.
reviews.author: J. Olson

reviews.text: This seminal offering in the gay drama genre features remarkable performances by Michael Stuhlbarg, Armie Hammer and Timothee Chalamet, who also plays the love interest in Lady Bird.
reviews.author: Kam Williams

reviews.text: A beautifully told story about discovering love, "Call Me by Your Name" is buoyed by the performance of its two lead actors.
reviews.author: Michael A. Smith

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name is one of the best films of 2017. That is indisputable. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jaime Fa de Lucas

reviews.text: Nothing happens and everything happens, the story's growing emotional power coming from subtle, complicated lead performances, exquisite pacing and dreamy, melancholy music from Sufjan Stevens.
reviews.author: Alison Gillmor

reviews.text: As pretty as a vacation postcard, and the actors deliver terrific performances that keep you engaged with their characters. (Full Content Review for Parents - Sex, Profanity, Nudity, etc. - also Available)
reviews.author: Jim Judy

reviews.text: Most importantly, Call Me By Your Name is an honest story of hearts on fire, broken, and then healed, with wise affection for its characters and their struggles, and a message of tolerance and love for us all.
reviews.author: Kirk Baird

reviews.text: Overall, Call Me by Your Name is a charming film, a sexy film and a family story. Though it drags in a couple of spots, it recovers nicely. What else could you want?
reviews.author: Edward Johnson-Ott

reviews.text: Films as special as this one are not often seen. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Nando Salvá

reviews.text: A very sensual story about how love and erotic passion can consume a person, particularly a budding teenager whose hormones encourage him (or her) to basically lust after anything in sight. Even a peach. Especially a peach.
reviews.author: Sean O'Connell

reviews.text: [The film] is able to move emotionally, from the rage of an idle summer to the icy winter...From the rhythm of an eighties song, to the soft, sharp and hurtful melody of Sufjan Stevens. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Violeta Kovacsics

reviews.text: Call it what you want but this movie is an instantly fond memory.
reviews.author: Steve Persall

reviews.text: I long to be as free as Hammer is in the scene in which Oliver dances, wildly and gracelessly, to The Psychedelic Furs' "Love My Way."
reviews.author: Christopher Lawrence

reviews.text: It's no Brokeback Mountain. There's no social, cultural, parental or "public" issue. It's about coming of age, not coming out. The guiltless, ephemeral exhilaration. It's an unforgettable, virtuoso achievement by Mr. Guadagnino.
reviews.author: Barry Paris

reviews.text: But the timeless torture of trying to decipher if his feelings are reciprocated, what to do about it if they are, and how each of them should feel about it, is rendered with poignant delicacy.
reviews.author: Lisa Jensen

reviews.text: Anyone who has had -- or has imagined -- a doomed youthful fling might be susceptible to this charming, bittersweet film.
reviews.author: Philip Martin

reviews.text: Michael Stuhlbarg gives a strong supporting performance as Elio's compassionate father and Hammer is very well-cast, but Chalamet owns the film with his passionate ambiguity.
reviews.author: Daniel Barnes

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name is a movie about two people falling in love. It's the kind of movie that's deceptively simple, but one that lingers. In other words, it's the best kind of movie.
reviews.author: Brad Keefe

reviews.text: ... seductive, finely wrought, and gently knowing film...
reviews.author: Kristian M. Lin

reviews.text: It's a sensual celebration of young love and lust.
reviews.author: Josh Bell

reviews.text: What could be dismissed as experimentation is instead framed with care and kindness as a first love, woozy and meaningful, bringing this fantasy world somewhere universal.
reviews.author: Tara Thorne

reviews.text: There is an air of the impossibly dreamy about the slowly unfolding events - and how the camera adores each man - but beneath its sublime scenery and beautiful people are the recognizable truths of too-real relationships.
reviews.author: Al Hoff

reviews.text: 'Call Me by Your Name' warmly and objectively captures the exhilaration and heartbreak of first love. It floats by like a cloud and softly embraces you like a tender hug.
reviews.author: Bob Bloom

reviews.text: It is pleasant enough, as a character study of Elio, but it doesn't offer much in terms of dramatic payoff.
reviews.author: Clint O'Connor

reviews.text: The film's last-minute twist is strictly spoiler territory, so all I'll say is that Call Me by Your Name is that rare achievement: a great film that only gets greater as it unfolds.
reviews.author: Rick Kisonak

reviews.text: The subtle build of anticipation makes the coming of age romance Call Me By Your Name so irresistibly delicious.
reviews.author: Diana Metzger

reviews.text: Watching Luca Guadagnino's sumptuous 1983-set romance feels like you're living inside someone else's cherished memory, hazy but still vivid.
reviews.author: Rob Thomas

reviews.text: The film wonderfully captures the intensity of that first love -carnal, fleeting and unforgettable - that leaves an indelible mark on everyone lucky enough to experience it. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Mario Alegre

reviews.text: I defy anyone to find a story of first love -- its triumphs and heartbreaks, its feverish beginnings and its sad endings -- that's as passionate or as moving as the one told in Call Me by Your Name.
reviews.author: Sean P. Means

reviews.text: The most romantic and sexiest film of 2017. A superb love story all across the board. Stays with you long after. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fico Cangiano

reviews.text: You can feel the stillness and the heat of this sultry, sensual summer in Italy. This is a glorious romance about falling in love with life itself, and living with gusto.
reviews.author: MaryAnn Johanson

reviews.text: ...it's like sitting through your oversharing neighbor's two-hour vacation slideshow.
reviews.author: Luke Y. Thompson

reviews.text: Desire and the flush of first love permeate this haunting film, whose Italian countryside setting echoes the beauty of the sentiments portrayed.
reviews.author: Louise Keller

reviews.text: Ravishingly pleasurable to look at purely as visual abstraction, even before we get in the business of the erotic depictions.
reviews.author: Tim Brayton

reviews.text: Recalls the talky, intellectual, but swoony summer romances of Eric Rohmer.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: It is an adaptation that is loving and faithful, but not slavishly so.
reviews.author: Boon Chan

reviews.text: There's just so much to discover in director Luca Guadagnino's take on a 2007 novel of the same name: Some beautiful Italian images, a few simply smart exchanges, and an '80s love story pertinent to our times, to name just a few.
reviews.author: John Urbancich

reviews.text: If there is a film that could be described as luscious, this is it.
reviews.author: Jan Lee

reviews.text: A kind of pastoral Arcadia in which all the senses reign. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ernesto Diezmartinez

reviews.text: The skill of Guadagnino's film is the time it takes to tease out Elio and Oliver's attraction, and to deepen our investment in how it plays out.
reviews.author: Steve Murray

reviews.text: This coming-of-age love story is all texture, tone and nuance...Luca Guadagnino has made a lovely cinematic feather. And it floats down beautifully, riding a soft breeze of melancholy and grace.
reviews.author: Tom Long

reviews.text: Guadagnino creates an evocative understanding of time and place, generating a sincere picture, and one that taps into the blur of primal longing.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: Could this film be any better? The cinematography beguiles. The dialogue is natural yet artful. The cast is first rate in every way
reviews.author: Peg Aloi

reviews.text: This is not simply a story of an introvert and an extrovert finding love with one another, but a portrait of desire, told with Guadagnino's unique and detailed attention to place.
reviews.author: Eloise Ross

reviews.text: Beautifying shot, hauntingly scored and terrifically acted, Call Me By Your Name is a film whose imagery (particularly its final shot) and characters will stay with you for days.
reviews.author: James Croot

reviews.text: The biggest achievement of Call Me by Your Name is that it manages to depict something universal about first love and first loss...
reviews.author: Rochelle Siemienowicz

reviews.text: Based on the acclaimed 2007 novel by Andre Aciman, Call Me By Your Name builds slowly, but surely into a truly great work of purely emotive cinema.
reviews.author: Leigh Paatsch

reviews.text: The most sensual film in ages; a transcendent exploration of first lust, first love, and first heartbreak seen through the eyes of a hormonal teenager.
reviews.author: Marlow Stern

reviews.text: Elio might have come across as a bit of a prat were it not for his flickering, on-the-edge-of-adulthood beauty, which helps to mitigate some of his... actions. His emotional vulnerability in the face of his desire makes him universally accessible.
reviews.author: Vicky Roach

reviews.text: One of the great coming-of-age movies, and also one of the great movies of teasing courtship
reviews.author: Stephen Silver

reviews.text: Too long at 132 minutes, Guadagnino's Call Me By Your Name still has much that impresses, from the beautiful, sometimes sun-struck cinematography to the occasionally cutting humour to Timothée's spot-on portrayal of surly teenage awkwardness.
reviews.author: David 'Mad Dog' Bradley

reviews.text: What truly elevates Call Me by Your Name is Michael Stuhlbarg, as the father to Chalamet and the teacher to Hammer, who gets an all-timer monologue that provides extra layers to the story.
reviews.author: Brian Formo

reviews.text: The spirit of Eric Rohmer lives vibrantly in the luscious-looking "Call Me by Your Name." But, unfortunately, not his talent.
reviews.author: Al Alexander

reviews.text: Enthralling and unforgettable. Yet, reenforces society's belief that the penis is ugly. Could physically gifted Armie Hammer has an ugly penis?
reviews.author: Victoria Alexander

reviews.text: This is, in the end, a simple and beautiful love story-a 'Brief Encounter' that happens to be gay, told with humanity and heart-wrenching truth. It is also, of course, one of the year's very best films.
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: The film luxuriates in the sun-kissed settings, languorous and largely devoid of conflict. It's an awfully nice movie, maybe even too nice?
reviews.author: Sean Burns

reviews.text: Hammer is exceptionally fine in the film... while Chalamet is perfect as the indecisive youth who is drawn to this exotic stranger in ways he himself can't fully comprehend.
reviews.author: David Stratton

reviews.text: It's a story less about the characters involved than it is about the dynamics between them, a late addition to the Symposium's accounts of the great god Love.
reviews.author: Matthew Lickona

reviews.text: Italy has never looked better on screen than it does in Sayombhu's Mukdeeprom's cinematography...
reviews.author: Sarah Boslaugh

reviews.text: Raw and honest, "Call Me By Your Name" exposes loss of innocence while celebrating the importance of one's first love in a mature, albeit graphic, way.
reviews.author: Jonathan W. Hickman

reviews.text: Just as the entrancing notes of the Psychedelic Furs' 'Love My Way' float through the Italian night in Call Me By Your Name, so too does the seductive, summertime-set romance's own charms.
reviews.author: Sarah Ward

reviews.text: Set in the northern Italian town of Crema and the surrounding countryside, Call Me By Your Name is a movie marinated in sensual pleasures, not all of them having to do with sex.
reviews.author: Robert Denerstein

reviews.text: Sultry and oh-so sexy, Call Me By Your Name is a masterful piece and romantic enough to win over even the hardest of hearts.
reviews.author: Becky Suter

reviews.text: The film is a great ode to the power of falling in love and discovering one's own truth and identity through the reflection of another.
reviews.author: Rob Dean

reviews.text: In the role of the young virgin, Timothée Chalamet is engaging as the story's anchor, yet one couldn't imagine this love-dream without Hammer's presence.
reviews.author: David Oppedisano

reviews.text: Although the material occasionally steers in the vicinity of a 1980s teen romance directed by Randall Kleiser (Summer Lovers fans, you know who you are), there's enough torment and joy generated to cast a real spell.
reviews.author: Robert Horton

reviews.text: "Call Me By Your Name" is a visually stunning coming-of-age story that boasts a star-making performance by Chalamet.
reviews.author: Calvin Wilson

reviews.text: An astonishing drama of sexual awakening that explores the exhilarations and anxieties that accompany first love.
reviews.author: Frederic and Mary Ann Brussat

reviews.text: [There is] a hole at the center of what would otherwise be-and still, semi-miraculously, is-a very involving, melancholy film.
reviews.author: Sean Nelson

reviews.text: A love affair is inevitable, but Guadagnino doesn't skim over Elio's prolonged longing, which is what makes Call Me by Your Name most potent as a coming-of-age picture, not a mere romance.
reviews.author: Kimberley Jones

reviews.text: It's probably best to take the movie for what it is: a look at a young, brilliant man who's trying to figure out his future -- and his sexuality.
reviews.author: Charles Ealy

reviews.text: Despite all its pain, love is always worth it, the film argues-and makes you believe.
reviews.author: Max Weiss

reviews.text: The film is beautifully shot and the performances are outstanding.
reviews.author: Bill Goodykoontz

reviews.text: Call My By Your Name, written for the screen by James Ivory, harkens back to the glory days of his partnership with the late Ismail Merchant, when the Merchant Ivory brand was an art-house staple.
reviews.author: Gary Thompson

reviews.text: You may not realize how strong the acting is until you replay the movie in your head later.
reviews.author: Ty Burr

reviews.text: ... Call Me By Your Name can only be described as a perfect film.
reviews.author: Sarah Watt

reviews.text: Isolated in the Lombardy region of Italy in a villa tucked away from the sexual politics of America, the tension of the film arises not purely from the proscribed sexuality but rather the intellectual foreplay.
reviews.author: Rubin Safaya

reviews.text: It's a striking reminder of the power of memory and the idea that love lost isn't love wasted, a message that rings beautifully clear and universal no matter how singular and lasting the story of Elio and Oliver is.
reviews.author: Allyson Johnson

reviews.text: Chalamet is a revelation.
reviews.author: Sara Michelle Fetters

reviews.text: What distinguish it from the competition are the dialogue and the acting.
reviews.author: Kelly Vance

reviews.text: Guadagnino has coaxed from his cast a film unmatched this year for lifelike rhythms and attention to human behavior.
reviews.author: Peter Canavese

reviews.text: It's a piercing glimpse of a young man's bright, confounding first love, the kind of love that brings disorientation and rhapsody.
reviews.author: Chris Vognar

reviews.text: Though much of Call Me By Your Name is lovely and well-crafted, it's never quite as subtle as the filmmakers seem to assume.
reviews.author: Jesse Hassenger

reviews.text: Slowly, as if in a delicate tango, the two move toward each other, and "Call Me By Your Name" becomes the story of a connection, both sexual and emotional.
reviews.author: Moira MacDonald

reviews.text: a glorious cinematic soak
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: Few films handle coming of age with as much grace and humanity as Call Me By Your Name and the audience is as transformed by the experience as the characters.
reviews.author: Wenlei Ma

reviews.text: As a gay love story, told without judgment and without apology, it's something that would have seemed unthinkable not so very long ago - and that feels like progress.
reviews.author: David Ehrenstein

reviews.text: Every performance in this film is captivating, and the story is sweet and pure.
reviews.author: Paula Farmer

reviews.text: If there's been a better film released during 2017, I haven't seen it.
reviews.author: Matthew Toomey

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name is a perfect, lazy, worry-free day, practically devoid of any real-world concerns and absolutely dripping with intellectual and artistic stimulation, and all manner of sexual enticement.
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: It is incredibly pleasant to spend a couple of hours with characters as unashamedly smart as this. It is rare these days to find English-speaking characters who revel in the pleasures of intellectual discussion, who celebrate each other's braininess.
reviews.author: CJ Johnson

reviews.text: By the end of this 132-minute journey, I had grown somewhat weary of the tug of war between the two leads, despite disarming efforts from Hammer and Chalamet.
reviews.author: Ken Eisner

reviews.text: There's a lot of the unspoken in Call Me by Your Name, a perceptive film about lust, jealousy, uncertainty, repression, and, maybe, love.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: [The] official synopsis assures us that "Elio's sophistication and intellectual gifts suggest he is already a fully-fledged adult," which neither jibes with the on-screen character nor makes up for the fact that Oliver is clearly a solid decade older.
reviews.author: Sherilyn Connelly

reviews.text: A complicated movie, erotic yet never graphic, heartfelt yet highly stylized. Chalamet delivers one of the year's best performances.
reviews.author: Rafer Guzman

reviews.text: ...so seductive, you might not notice there is a troubling streak of hedonism at its core.
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: One of the year's most romantic movies, and also one of the best.
reviews.author: Peter Howell

reviews.text: It's a rare movie that knows when to move and when to stay still. Call Me By Your Name ... is just such a film, lazy as a late-afternoon dragonfly one moment, rash and rushed as young love the next.
reviews.author: Chris Knight

reviews.text: A lot of Call Me By Your Name has a hazy, meandering quality to it. In its final moments, as summer draws to a close, Ivory's script and the performances shift into sharp focus.
reviews.author: Alan Zilberman

reviews.text: ... it's a beautiful coming-of-age story that hasn't been told before.
reviews.author: Erika W. Smith

reviews.text: A spellbinding, almost ecstatically beautiful movie that gains even more heft and meaning in its final transcendent moments.
reviews.author: Ann Hornaday

reviews.text: "Call Me by Your Name" is enough to make you move to the town of Crema, even if your rational self realizes the director Luca Guadagnino trades in a heightened, miragelike state of mythic yearning.
reviews.author: Michael Phillips

reviews.text: A coming-of-age story exploring one's first experience with true love and sexual uncertainty, including the hypnotic pleasures of both physical and intellectual affection balanced against bittersweet heartbreak
reviews.author: Robert Kojder

reviews.text: Both a heartwarming and heartwrenching tale of love, loss and discovery that could be my favorite film of the year. Timothee Chalamet, Armie Hammer and Michael Stuhlbarg give award-caliber performances in a film that is an important as it is beautiful.
reviews.author: Mark Ellis

reviews.text: A deep and complex journey into discovery, Call Me By Your Name is an announcement that Timothee Chalamet is a new force to be reckoned with in cinema. Certainly a top contender for awards this season!
reviews.author: Kristian Harloff

reviews.text: "Call Me By Your Name" is transcendent in its first hour, communicating much through the camera's evocation of nature and the screenplay's clear yet subtle dialogue.
reviews.author: Mick LaSalle

reviews.text: A truly escapist romantic fantasy, the movie is awash in the romance of its setting long before things get serious between its protagonists.
reviews.author: Jim Slotek

reviews.text: Luca Guadagnino's films are so tangible, you could live inside of them, and you'd be happy to stay there.
reviews.author: Simon Miraudo

reviews.text: Subtly stirring and sensitive drama - about a sensuous summer that could change the course of a boy's life.
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: I'm still uncertain if I buy 31-year- old Armie Hammer as a 24-year- old, but man, Luca Guadagnino's Call Me by Your Name sure does sell its love story.
reviews.author: Aaron Yap

reviews.text: It's a story of first love: impossible, impermanent, and passionate.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: Gorgeous Tuscan scenery forms the backdrop for a 17-year-old's coming of sexual age. He has the kind of father we all probably wanted.
reviews.author: Harvey S. Karten

reviews.text: In what might be the most romantic movie of the year, Call Me by Your Name dispenses with cliché while focusing on the universal fantasy of first love.
reviews.author: Annlee Ellingson

reviews.text: Luca Guadagnino's tale of budding gay romance in 1980s Italy is one of the most mesmerizing films of the year.
reviews.author: David Sims

reviews.text: Compared with. . .any number of films dealing with down-to-earth sexual feelings that go wild. . .Call Me By Your Name is trite. . .Few recent films have so bluntly proclaimed moral pessimism.
reviews.author: Armond White

reviews.text: [Call Me by Your Name] won't need to guilt, shame or convince to win people over. Instead this coming-of-age romance resonates something more pervasive.
reviews.author: Gary Shannon

reviews.text: Luca Guadagnino's romantic drama Call Me By Your Name sneaks up on you -- by the end, it stings with the lingering ache of a late-summer sunburn.
reviews.author: April Wolfe

reviews.text: Veteran director James Ivory, the screenwriter here, has adapted Aciman's novel with delicacy and discretion. Guadagnino's visual style, on the other hand, is so swoony that one might require a fainting couch.
reviews.author: Carrie Rickey

reviews.text: The direction by Luca Guadagnino is reminiscent of Bertolucci's sensitivity at its best, the fabulous cinematography by Sayombhu Mukdeeprom rapturously captures the rich work of art that is Italy in summer, and the actors are to die for.
reviews.author: Rex Reed

reviews.text: It's the rare movie that dares to show us what unconditional love is, not just from romantic interests, but also from the people who love us the most and know us the best.
reviews.author: Alex Abad-Santos

reviews.text: Gorgeous, lyrical story of first love and desire during an Italian summer hits you right in the heart.
reviews.author: Pete Hammond

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name makes you remember how it felt to realize, as you became an adult, that your best experiences are ephemeral-that by the time you recognize an experience for what it is, it's already a memory.
reviews.author: K. Austin Collins

reviews.text: Although it ends on a powerful, bittersweet chord, the movie is a bit too determinedly soothing for comfort.
reviews.author: Peter Rainer

reviews.text: Guadagnino has made the exploration of love and sexuality his mandate.
reviews.author: Don Kaye

reviews.text: So assailed are we by reports of harmful pleasures, and of the coercive male will being imposed through lust, that it comes as a relief to be reminded, in such style, of consensual joy.
reviews.author: Anthony Lane

reviews.text: "Call Me By Your Name" is awash in the magical splendor of beautiful sunshine, luscious foods and first love.
reviews.author: Jeanne Kaplan

reviews.text: "Call Me By Your Name" is not simply a movie that will be embraced by the LGBT community. It is a story about love and friendship that should be appreciated by everybody.
reviews.author: David Kaplan

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name burns hot from beginning to end.
reviews.author: Matt Patches

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name is a beautiful and powerful coming of age love story with remarkable performances from Armie Hammer and Timothée Chalamet.
reviews.author: Molly Freeman

reviews.text: Luminous, breathtaking, and so extraordinarily intimate one can scarcely believe something so miraculous has been captured in front of a camera by actors, the picture is close to a miracle. "Call Me by Your Name" is a motion picture to cherish.
reviews.author: Dustin Putman

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name is a work that I admired for its technique and performances. I did not, however, enjoy the way it made me feel.
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: You don't just watch Luca Guadagnino's movies, you swoon into them.
reviews.author: Manohla Dargis

reviews.text: "Call Me by Your Name is a great love story, and it is also a story about the way that Guadagnino's camera loves and brings out Hammer as an actor who can express joy or inner turmoil with a glance."
reviews.author: Dan Callahan

reviews.text: There's an ethereal quality to Guadagnino's work that shapes its every moment. The story unfolds as if in a dream, a memory of a sun-swept time when the promise of love emerged and brought with it all that's terrible and wonderful in the world.
reviews.author: Robert Levin

reviews.text: ... an aesthetic journey that pays off in a stunning third act when the endless summer quickens to light speed and is gone in a flash.
reviews.author: Lindsey Bahr

reviews.text: Raw, and real, and profoundly, indelibly moving.
reviews.author: Glen Weldon

reviews.text: First love is as much about hesitancy as it is about exuberance, and Ivory and Guadagnino perfectly capture that sweet turmoil. This isn't just an instant LGBT classic; this is one of the great movie love stories, for audiences of all stripes.
reviews.author: Alonso Duralde

reviews.text: Elio and Oliver's relationship has an authentic tenderness under the direction of Luca Guadagnino, who's created the best coming-of-age story in recent years.
reviews.author: Garrett Schaffel

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name is one of the great movies of the year.
reviews.author: Stephen Rebello

reviews.text: Luca Guadagnino's exquisite adaptation of André Aciman's exquisite novel...casts a truly seductive spell.
reviews.author: Gary M. Kramer

reviews.text: ... remarkable for how it turns literature into pure cinema, all emotion and image and heady sensation.
reviews.author: Alissa Wilkinson

reviews.text: Chalamet, a world away from his fine work in "Lady Bird," is a young actor to watch.
reviews.author: Amy Rowe

reviews.text: Strong sexual content, adult themes in gay romance.
reviews.author: Michael Ordoña

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name is like a treasured artifact from your youth, back when withering looks from a first love felt like daggers to the heart.
reviews.author: Mara Reinstein

reviews.text: The way it explores at length the sweet and sour aspects of first love is worth savoring.
reviews.author: Brian Truitt

reviews.text: .. it isn't just one of the best films of 2017, but it is also what cinema is really all about, too.
reviews.author: Gregory Wakeman

reviews.text: The small miracle of the movie isn't just that it tells a gay love story with such unreserved tenderness, but that it makes the fate of a romance not meant to last feel like much more than exquisitely framed filmmaking.
reviews.author: Leah Greenblatt

reviews.text: Filmed in luminous 35mm, as attentive to the colors and sounds of nature as it is to the beauty of art, architecture, and yes, Armie Hammer, this is the kind of movie you live in as much as watch.
reviews.author: Dana Stevens

reviews.text: This gorgeous story is an aching, haunting summer love that fills your heart with love. True to that summer love feeling, it's hard to shake this one.
reviews.author: Courtney Howard

reviews.text: Luca Guadagnino's film of first love is beautiful, capped by a scene I may, happily, never forget.
reviews.author: Joanna Langfield

reviews.text: Swooningly romantic, sensually filmed tale of the summer love affair between a teenage boy and his dad's visiting grad-student intern.
reviews.author: Kevin Lally

reviews.text: One of the very best films of the year. Guadagnino, a master cinema sensualist, and his award-caliber actors Chalamet, Hammer and Stuhlbarg create a love story for the ages and a new film classic. Let it in.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: What makes Call Be By Your Name stand out from the films it will be compared to is Guadagnino's play on juxtapositions, which go much deeper than merely an angsty teen with an introspective soul.
reviews.author: Susan Kemp

reviews.text: A lush and vibrant masterpiece about first love set amid the warm, sunny skies, gentle breezes and charming, tree-lined roads of northern Italy.
reviews.author: Christy Lemire

reviews.text: Languor, lust; yearning, yielding: Call Me by Your Name-a sexy, melancholy summer idyll directed by the supreme cine-sybarite Luca Guadagnino-lushly shows how desire is deftly articulated, even when not explicitly labeled or spoken.
reviews.author: Melissa Anderson

reviews.text: A lovely place to visit but not particularly absorbing as a narrative, even though Armie Hammer gives an impressive performance.
reviews.author: William Bibbiani

reviews.text: Refreshingly fun, erotic, non-judgmental and both intellectually and emotionally smart.
reviews.author: Bob Strauss

reviews.text: [Call me By Your Name] gracefully weaves an examination of internalized homophobia and anti-Semitism, among other things, into its slow-burn romance.
reviews.author: Angelo Muredda

reviews.text: It's a rare remembrance of love that knows the heartbreak after is just as tied up in the experience as the joy during. More, perhaps.
reviews.author: Jason Bailey

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name is more invitingly heartfelt and less baroque than the director's previous films, and skillfully captures ... the languor of the summer mood.
reviews.author: Molly Haskell

reviews.text: Chalamet, however, is mesmerizing in the film. He carries the weight of the emotional layers so beautifully and effortlessly.
reviews.author: Candice Frederick

reviews.text: The achievement of the director Luca Guadagnino is to create in the absence of any obvious opposition a picture that is still taut with inner tensions.
reviews.author: Ryan Gilbey

reviews.text: Luca Guadagnino's latest is both alluring and alienating in equal measure. That's part and parcel of its beauty.
reviews.author: Siddhant Adlakha

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name is a very tasteful exercise. This is one of those movie environments that admits only the intelligent, the well-dressed and the culturally sophisticated.
reviews.author: Donald Clarke

reviews.text: Guadagnino hasn't adapted Aciman's novel so much as interrogated its moods, going at it con brio.
reviews.author: Tom Shone

reviews.text: Based on Andre Aciman's novel, this gorgeous-looking and beautifully atmospheric film has echoes of all sorts of good things, including Guadagnino's A Bigger Splash and I Am Love.
reviews.author: Matthew Bond

reviews.text: Heat hangs heavy in the air in this beguiling, almost overpoweringly sensual drama, which is languidly paced, and filled with the sleepy sights and sounds of a northern Italian summer.
reviews.author: Paul Whitington

reviews.text: Chalamet, with his restless, impatient physicality and a face as sensual and sculpted as a fallen angel from a Caravaggio painting, is quite simply astonishing.
reviews.author: Wendy Ide

reviews.text: What sets this movie apart is the way it creates characters who feel like they have vivid, full lives even when they're not on-screen. So as they collide and connect, everything feels organic and full of possibilities.
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: Whether a paternal benediction is what Elio can or wants to hear, Call Me By Your Name is right to speak it. Philosophically as well as visually, this movie is a beaut.
reviews.author: Matt Wolf

reviews.text: The camera pays an almost hyperreal attention to detail, poring over certain words and touches with the obsessiveness of an infatuated teenager.
reviews.author: Catherine Wheatley

reviews.text: What makes this film special? Aside from the fluid script, inventive camerawork and three uncanny songs by Sufjan Stevens, it's surely the acting, which seems scooped from the performers' marrow.
reviews.author: Charlotte O'Sullivan

reviews.text: It's a nicely observed film, rich in period and mood, and lifted by one really superb performance, by young Chalamet.
reviews.author: Brian Viner

reviews.text: Graceful, heartfelt and infused with a generous spirit, this is a rare and lovely drama.
reviews.author: Allan Hunter

reviews.text: A mediocre film would use Elio's parents as a one-note backdrop to his affair: oblivious, disbelieving, disapproving or draconian. Here they are none of those things.
reviews.author: Ed Potton

reviews.text: The two leads are utterly superb, but it's Chalamet who delivers a damned flawless performance as the virginal and inquisitive Elio - as expressive as he is captivating.
reviews.author: Jamie East

reviews.text: What makes the film so magical is the extraordinary delicacy, formal daring and insight with which Guadagnino tackles such familiar material.
reviews.author: Geoffrey Macnab

reviews.text: The performances are casually brilliant...
reviews.author: Alistair Harkness

reviews.text: The twists and turns here will mirror something - or better still someone - from your own life as the story unfolds in drawing rooms, piazzas, discos and bars. If every film flowed as beautifully as this one we'd rarely see daylight.
reviews.author: Harry Guerin

reviews.text: Saturated with poetic languor and a deeply sophisticated sensuality.
reviews.author: Peter Bradshaw

reviews.text: It's an incomparably lovely period romance, as warm and therapeutic as the sunlight that suffuses every frame.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: Powerfully emotional and exquisitely romantic, this is a beautifully made and wonderfully acted film that has every element working together in perfect harmony.
reviews.author: Matthew Turner

reviews.text: ... a work as heart-warming as it is gorgeous.
reviews.author: Stephen Porzio

reviews.text: The film's genius is that it never settles into a steady track. Shots are often held too long or too short, by orthodox rules. Piano runs suddenly ambush the soundtrack.
reviews.author: Nigel Andrews

reviews.text: A beautiful film about love and longing, one you'll want (and need) to watch again and again and again.
reviews.author: Adam Woodward

reviews.text: Peachy keen. A luminous, sun-kissed Italian love story brimming with warmth, passion and feeling. This is utterly unmissable.
reviews.author: Josh Winning

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name an ode to love and its precipices... [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Erick Estrada

reviews.text: Part heady romance, part coming-of-age tale, and one of the most beautiful recent examples of both.
reviews.author: Josh Slater-Williams

reviews.text: Though Call Me By Your Name overall is a little disappointing, especially after all the hype it has received, these final scenes are inarguably majestic.
reviews.author: Chloe Walker

reviews.text: This is exquisite filmmaking, from an aesthetically accomplished director who you can feel falling in love with these characters as much as the audience are.
reviews.author: Alistair Ryder

reviews.text: I wasn't enamoured by Call My By Your Name until its final half hour, by which point I was swept away in a sea of love, longing and, ultimately, loss.
reviews.author: Ryan Morris

reviews.text: This is an erotic and mesmerizing movie that exemplifies cinematic artistry in scope, theme, and tone.
reviews.author: Jordan Ruimy

reviews.text: A film that's at once light, joyful and emotionally devastating, with deeply affecting central performances. A full-hearted romantic masterpiece.
reviews.author: Olly Richards

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name thinks about cruising and playing games, but never makes up its mind.
reviews.author: Kyle Turner

reviews.text: Not only offers a feast for your eyes, but also imagery so evocative it'll make your heart race and your fingers tingle with the memory of sun and touches from summers past.
reviews.author: Kristy Puchko

reviews.text: There's something quite touching about watching Stuhlbarg in Call Me by Your Name eight years after his breakthrough in A Serious Man.
reviews.author: Adam Nayman

reviews.text: Anchored by a duo of riveting performances by Timothée Chalamet and Armie Hammer, "Call Me by Your Name" is a spiritual and effervescent experience.
reviews.author: Clayton Davis

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name is a fairly straightforward coming-of-age story that's at its finest in moments when the relationships take on larger meanings than their literal context implies, and Luca Guadagnino finds evocative aesthetic expressions for them.
reviews.author: Sam C. Mac

reviews.text: Come for the buzz around a scandalous peach scene, stay for the viscous chemistry between the two leads.
reviews.author: Alexandra Pollard

reviews.text: Italy has never looked so inviting.
reviews.author: Dwight Brown

reviews.text: A melancholic film that will inevitably evoke this singular restlessness of the first love. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Oscar Uriel

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name warmly embraces the fickleness of first love, the confusing elements of queer desire, and-above all-the tranquility of total togetherness.
reviews.author: Tomas Trussow

reviews.text: [Call Me By Your Name] may be the best new film I've seen this year.
reviews.author: John Powers

reviews.text: A timeless romance with a preserved space in the books of cinema history. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Orlando Maldonado

reviews.text: The "somewhere in Northern Italy" setting is a character all its own in the movie with its hidden ponds, cute towns, and a rustic villa.
reviews.author: Jason Guerrasio

reviews.text: It can try the patience.
reviews.author: Kate Taylor

reviews.text: The film's heart is found not with the two leads but in a gut-wrenching monologue by Michael Stuhlburg as Elio's father.
reviews.author: Glenn Sumi

reviews.text: Filled with moments of pure bliss, this deeply touching film is a romance for the ages.
reviews.author: Shane Slater

reviews.text: Yes, a lot of these elements can be universal, but it seems undeniable to me that a gay audience will bring something altogether unique to their viewing of such a film.
reviews.author: Glenn Dunks

reviews.text: The film makes a defense of erudition as another pleasure of life, comparable to the discovery of sexuality and the first love that moves its main story. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Miguel Muñoz Garnica

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name succeeds as it offers a central queer romance as a bond based on true love and understanding, a connection that can be formed by all.
reviews.author: Alex Lines

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name is a masterpiece.
reviews.author: George Fenwick

reviews.text: Guadagnino's new film is also his sweetest, calmest, and loveliest. It sneaks up on you. Throughout, Guadagnino captures what first love feels like, in all its fumbling, awkward, confusing, terrifying, joyous glory.
reviews.author: Alex Heeney

reviews.text: First love has rarely been depicted as beautifully or as movingly as it is in Luca Guadagnino's Call Me By Your Name, an adaptation of the André Aciman.
reviews.author: Angie Han

reviews.text: The bond between Elio and Oliver grows tentatively, but unleashes forceful emotions that reverberate through all the relationships in a film both hilarious and gorgeously sad, that crackles with sexual tension.
reviews.author: Carmen Gray

reviews.text: Stripped of the baggage that so often complicates and corrupts queer romance, Call Me by Your Name is allowed to flourish as an unfiltered evocation of the agony and ecstasy of first love.
reviews.author: Paul O'Callaghan

reviews.text: Luca Guadagnino's film proves affecting as a chronicle of a young man learning to embrace his more emotional side.
reviews.author: Kenji Fujishima

reviews.text: A major addition to the queer cinema canon.
reviews.author: Patrick Gamble

reviews.text: The film triumphs thanks to Chalamet's performance, as it's hard to recall seeing a young actor turn in as accomplished a performance as he manages here.
reviews.author: Stefan Pape

reviews.text: Equally a portrayal of good parenting as it is honest sexual becoming.
reviews.author: Fred Topel

reviews.text: In attaching sinuous style and casual sexiness to a universal ache, [Luca] Guadagnino has come away with real wisdom. Sweet and salty, his movie burns like a suntan.
reviews.author: Joshua Rothkopf

reviews.text: Feels both fresh and vintage, and watching it, you can almost feel the warm Italian sun and smell the fresh breeze billowing through the orchards. A trip to a bucolic place of young love and intellectual rigour, it's an intoxicating work.
reviews.author: Jason Gorber

reviews.text: Committed with the utmost beauty, humanity, and sexuality.
reviews.author: Michael Arbeiter

reviews.text: Guadagnino's film is one of swooning sentiment, but it never once cheapens or diminishes the rich emotion of its story for extraneous impact.
reviews.author: Dominick Suzanne-Mayer

reviews.text: It's hard to think of many movies that have so successfully appealed to both the intellectual and the erotic since the heydays of Patrice Chéreau and André Téchiné.
reviews.author: Sam Adams

reviews.text: An effortlessly beautiful ode to the loves destined to last a lifetime even when those we love are no longer in our lives.
reviews.author: Rob Hunter

reviews.text: Call Me by Your Name achieves a rush of nostalgia for first love and first loss.
reviews.author: Tyler Coates

reviews.text: Drenched in sunlight, the movie is filled with warmth (and hotness), devoid of sappy melodrama but rich with honest emotion that transcends boundaries of sexual orientation.
reviews.author: Eric D. Snider

reviews.text: Unforgettable on every level, the kind of film that has the power to move and inspire.
reviews.author: Brian Tallerico

reviews.text: A swirling wonder, a film about coming of age, about the secrets of youth, the magic of summer, the beauty of Italy.
reviews.author: Richard Lawson

reviews.text: Any of Guadagnino's cinematic trips to sunny Italy are worth taking, but Call Me By Your Name may be his most tender and sumptuous work yet.
reviews.author: Oliver Whitney

reviews.text: A powerfully erotic and affecting love story, albeit one so closely and intimately observed that the term "slow burn" seems almost inadequate.
reviews.author: Justin Chang

reviews.text: A sumptuously filmed, beautifully acted love story with Armie Hammer's best performance to date.
reviews.author: Chris Bumbray

reviews.text: A feat of accentuated sound design and arresting cinematography, luxuriating in the beauty of Italy.
reviews.author: Jordan Raup

reviews.text: The final beats of Guadagnino's adaptation galvanize two hours of simmering uncertainty into a gut-wrenchingly wistful portrait of two people trying to find themselves before it's too late.
reviews.author: David Ehrlich

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name is a triumph of humanity.
reviews.author: Mike Ryan

reviews.text: Based on André Aciman's 2007 novel, Luca Guadagnino directs a sexy, stunning film that will tunnel its way into your heart and live there.
reviews.author: Meredith Borders

reviews.text: Call Me By Your Name's erotic tension wouldn't crackle so loudly without the chemistry between its leads.
reviews.author: A.A. Dowd

reviews.text: 'Call Me by Your Name' is a triumph in every regard
reviews.author: Adam Chitwood

reviews.text: It's a beautiful, supremely touching performance from Chalamet which gives this surprisingly safe story a deeply-moving purity.
reviews.author: Fionnuala Halligan

reviews.text: It's not to be missed.
reviews.author: Sara Stewart

reviews.text: Love and intimacy between two male characters has never truly felt this real or emotionally heartbreaking.
reviews.author: Gregory Ellwood

reviews.text: Guadagnino, most famous for the far splashier features I Am Love and A Bigger Splash, finds exactly the right tone for the material, which is understated and filled with paternal affection.
reviews.author: Boyd van Hoeij

reviews.text: Even as he beguiles us with mystery, Guadagnino recreates Elio's life-changing summer with such intensity that we might as well be experiencing it first-hand.
reviews.author: Peter Debruge

synopsis: It's the summer of 1983, and precocious 17-year-old Elio Perlman is spending the days with his family at their 17th-century villa in Lombardy, Italy. He soon meets Oliver, a handsome doctoral student who's working as an intern for Elio's father. Amid the sun-drenched splendor of their surroundings, Elio and Oliver discover the heady beauty of awakening desire over the course of a summer that will alter their lives forever.
